results.title: Tomorrow is now
results.brief_description: The work of the Post Office research laboratories in Melbourne in a brief coverage of six of the many current research projects. These are: testing of telephones, operation of the time and frequency standard, the effect and control of plume radiation on aerial systems, microwave propagation testing, experiments with optical fibres and trials conducted with a computer controlled exchange.

results.title: Tomorrow begins today
results.creator_credit: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East
results.brief_description: Dealing with the refugee problem in the Middle East, including the difficulties faced by the children. As a result of armed conflict in 1948 in the Holy Land, nearly one million Arabs became refugees. This film shows the steps taken by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency to help in educating and resettling these people.

results.title: Tomorrow's today
results.creator_credit: Henry Lewes and Park Film Studios
results.brief_description: A film record of children’s paintings, showing the manner in which the environment effects the choice of subject and the style of work itself. The paintings come from school children in the East End of London and provide a grim picture of the daily scene that confronts them.

results.title: Tomorrow's end. Episodes 1-6
results.brief_description: At the end of the first series of “The Girl from Tomorrow”, Jenny has been badly injured and needs to travel with Alana to her home in the year 3000 to recover. Alana is a 13 year old girl who travelled back in her time capsule to Sydney 1990 where she met Jenny and her brother, Petey. This series, “Tomorrow’s End” continues the adventures of Alana, Peter and Jenny. This time they travel forward in time to join Alana’s family, but the evil Silverthorn travels with them and tricks them so he can trap them in his world of 2500.

results.title: Tomorrow's children
results.brief_description: Scenes of healthy people of many nations are juxtaposed with malnourished and crowded children of other countries to open this film which discusses the way in which population growth has interfered with the ecological balance. Discusses family planning programs as one way of alleviating the problem.

results.title: Tomi Ungerer: storyteller
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: An interview with Tomi Ungerer, a delightful man and gifted visual storyteller. Includes animated sequences based on three of his published illustrated books: “Moon man”, “The Three robbers” and “The Beast of M. Racine”.

results.title: Tom Phillips
results.creator_credit: David Rowan, Margaret Williams, Arbor Films and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Covers many aspects of Tom Phillips’ work which includes painting, drawing, graphics and music. Features commentary by Phillips about his two collage works “Humument” and “Benches” providing a fascinating insight into the mind of this original and creative artist.

results.title: Tom Cruise as Ironman - Deepfake Theater

constellations_other.name: Dismissing the truth
constellations_other.description: The dismissal of Gough Whitlam by Governor-General Sir John Kerr is one of the most controversial moments in Australian politics. Whitlam’s rebuttal imploring the electorate to ‘maintain the rage’ was immortalised on TV and took on the gravitas of Shakespearean tragedy.

results.description: Years after the release of Iron Man in 2008, rumours persisted that Tom Cruise had been set to play Tony Stark, the role immortalised by Robert Downey Jr., in the 2008 blockbuster directed by Jon Favreau. In August 2019, Deepfake Theater couldn’t resist the urge to ‘magic up’ an alternate version of Iron Man’s trajectory through the Marvel Cinematic Universe in a video that employed deepfake technology to superimpose Cruise over scenes shot with Robert Downey Jr. across the gamut of Marvel Studios’ back catalogue.
description_for_label: Years after the release of Iron Man in 2008, rumours persisted that Tom Cruise had been set to play Tony Stark, the role immortalised by Robert Downey Jr., in the 2008 blockbuster directed by Jon Favreau. In August 2019, Deepfake Theater couldn’t resist the urge to ‘magic up’ an alternate version of Iron Man’s trajectory through the Marvel Cinematic Universe in a video that employed deepfake technology to superimpose Cruise over scenes shot with Robert Downey Jr. across the gamut of Marvel Studios’ back catalogue.
